citeinfo.title: Biological soil crusts of Arabian sabkhat

descript.abstract: Most arid and semi-arid landscapes have a limited cover of vascular vegetation with the soil spaces between vascular plants containing communities of cyanobacteria, green algae, microfungi, and other bacteria. In the top few millimeters of soil, the cyanobacterial and microfungal filaments weave among soil grains and create a crust that helps to stabilize and protect soil surfaces from erosion. USGS scientist Jayne Belnap has studied the importance of biological soil crusts in many regions, including the arid Arabian sabkhat where crusts have important ecological roles. For example, biological soil crusts help to input nitrogen and carbon, maintain nutrients required by plants in a biologically available form, influence local hydrology, affect the establishment of vascular, and decrease soil erosion from either wind or water. Although no studies have directly addressed the ecological role of soil crusts on sabkha surfaces, there are many studies from hot desert ecosystems that are applicable to these systems. However, it is hoped that further studies will determine more specifically how soil crusts affect the ecology of Arabian sabkhat.
